snippet: The 14 percent uptick for the two groups reverses a years-long decline in admissions to the city’s specialized schools, where admittance is based on a single test.
abstract: Admissions statistics released by New York City's Education Dept show that the number of black and Latino students accepted at one of the city's eight specialized high schools increased from a year earlier by 14 percent; uptick for the two groups reverses a years-long decline in admissions to the city's elite schools, where admittance is based on a single test.
lead_paragraph: The 14 percent uptick for the two groups reverses a years-long decline in admissions to the city’s specialized schools, where admittance is based on a single test.

headline.seo: More Blacks and Latinos Admitted to Elite New York High Schools
headline.main: More Blacks and Latinos Admitted to Elite New York High Schools
headline.print_headline: More Blacks and Latinos Admitted to Elite New York High Schools
